details.title: Coverage Modeling and Optimal Maintenance Frequency of an Automated Restoration Mechanism

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Financial & Manage. Eng., Univ. of the Aegean, Chios, Greece

p: Agapios N. Platis is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Financial and Management Engineering of the University of the Aegean. Formerly, he was Lecturer in the Department of Information and Communication Systems Engineering at the University of the Aegean He is also tutor of the Hellenic Open University. He received a degree in Computer Science Engineering (diplôme d’ingénieur en Génie Informatique) in 1993, a Master (DEA) in Systems Control in 1994, and a PhD in System Reliability in 1997, all from the Université de Technologie de Compiègne (UTC). He has been employed in Framatome, IBM France, and EDF (Electricité de France). The French Government has awarded him Knight of the Order of the Academic Palms in 2006. He has published over 50 research papers in international journals and conference proceedings, and is currently supervising 3 PhD students. His research interests are focused on the stochastic modeling of highly available, and highly reliable systems.

p: Emmanouil G. Drosakis has received a Bachelor degree in business administration in 1995, and a M.B.A. degree in operations and production management in 2006 from the University of the Aegean, Greece. After his MBA, he started a research collaboration in the field of dependability assessment, and is currently a candidate for beginning a PhD dissertation in the Department of Financial and Management Engineering at the University of the Aegean. His research interests include modeling, and evaluation of system's dependability.

authors.name: Emmanouil G. Drosakis

details.abstract: In this paper, the coverage modeling of an automated restoration mechanism with two components is studied, and optimal maintenance frequencies are determined. Failures and repairs are exponentially distributed for the two components, while the failures of the automated mechanism follow a Weibull distribution. A corrective maintenance policy is considered for each component whereas, for the automated restoration mechanism, an additional preventive maintenance is taken into account. The system is modeled with a continuous time Markov chain and two performability indicators: one performability indicator modeling the downtime, and a second one modeling the overall operational cost. Consequently, two optimal maintenance frequencies are derived: first by minimizing the downtime, and second by minimizing the overall operational cost. A numerical example is used to evaluate the applicability of the proposed method.
